text: do you know the difference between good and bad risk as a Trader my guess is most Traders out there have an idea on a spectrum but it's not really well- defined so the goal of this video is to walk you through in detail good risk versus bad risk with examples and then at the end of the video I'm going to go through some best practices that I've learned from Trading over the years what's up everybody welcome back to all the outliers and a shout out to the patreon family you guys make content like this Poss for everybody else so thank you for the support let's get straight into it so first let's start with level setting how do we make money in the markets well really there's these two broad buckets you can either earn the risk-free rate so kind of Government Bond investing something like that which is seen as very very low risk which typically will correspond to pretty low returns or you can take risk of some sort you can take speculative risk and guess on a direction you can offload risk for another Trader by assuming their risk via selling cash secured puts where somebody's buying puts for protection and you're selling them there are lots of different ways to take risk but the idea here is for us to understand the difference between good and bad risk and then most importantly to understand what our individual risk profiles are so

text: secured puts where somebody's buying puts for protection and you're selling them there are lots of different ways to take risk but the idea here is for us to understand the difference between good and bad risk and then most importantly to understand what our individual risk profiles are so for the next part of this I want you to think about yourself how do you think about risk because most people fall closer to one of two spectrums either you're very risk averse you don't want to take risk you look to hedge risk at most opportunities and unfortunately this typically means you're not going to make any money because as you hedge all of this risk all of that incurs cost which pretty much moves you closer to this risk-free rate or you could be the kind of person that's very risk open you don't really think about it probably not as much as you should and sooner or later you put on risk that you didn't fully think about and it runs you over in eviscerates your account the idea here is to fall somewhere in the middle because notice here how I have R to R this is risk and this is reward risk and reward are intimately tied to one another it's not a onetoone relationship you can find really great risk opportunities which we're we're going to talk about here I come oh here I come oh but in general you would do well

text: than just selling the short put that's not necessarily the case because the cost to hedge via this long put in the long run this trade might actually not even be positively expectant meaning it can lose money in the long run compared to this one so when we're thinking about risk you have to think about this idea of catastrophic risk if there's a big move but then also the systematic risk what does this do if we deploy it in the long run this is also very akin to the common idea that really high probability strategies make money that's also not so much the case you can have something with a 90 plus win rate but if the metrics of the trade in terms of average win size versus average loss size don't make sense even with the 90 win rate you can still lose money so that leads us to this idea of good risk I kind of was sprinkling this in as we ran through the other scenarios so the very first thing a good risk is one that is defined so if we're to trade this cash secured put or naked short put in AMD defining that risk that's a good risk to take because then we can analyze that defined risk that we're setting compared to the profit potential and see if it makes sense next is unknown risk I call this researched risk but essentially this is just where we don't have

metadata.title: The Trader’s Guide to Effective Risk Management
metadata.description:
💡 Join the Outlier Pro Patreon Community for weekly livestreams, private community, market & trade analysis, direct Q&A, & more. https://www.patreon.com/OutlierTrading
► Free Guide for Beginner Options Traders. https://www.outliertrading.io/guide
► Subscribe to the Outlier Insights Newsletter. https://outliertrading.substack.com/
► Join the FREE Outlier Community Discord. https://discord.gg/hYGZUEJpve
► Listen to the Outlier Podcast. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLAFDZ3YyC4rSe9h-s9XvtxktSm16-7-9L
► Learn About Erik. https://www.outliertrading.io 📨 Subscribe to the Outlier Insights Newsletter. https://esinvests.substack.com/
💡 Join the FREE Outlier Community Discord. https://discord.gg/hYGZUEJpve
📈 Join the Outlier Patreon for exclusive content: weekly workshops, templates, trade reviews, & more. https://www.patreon.com/erik_esinvests
📻 Listen to the Outlier Podcast. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLAFDZ3YyC4rSe9h-s9XvtxktSm16-7-9L
ℹ️ Free Compound Interest Calculator: https://www.esinvests.com/resources
🔎Learn About Erik. https://www.esinvests.com

00:00 - Introduction
   - Overview of the video
   - Purpose: Understanding good vs. bad risk in trading

01:00 - Making Money in the Markets
   - Risk-free rate vs. taking risk
   - Different ways to take on risk in trading

02:00 - Understanding Personal Risk Profile
   - Identifying risk aversion and risk openness
   - Balancing risk and reward in trading

03:00 - Bad Risk: Undefined Risk
   - Importance of defining risk in trades
   - Example: Using a stop-loss in undefined risk trades

04:30 - Bad Risk: Unknown Risk
   - Identifying and managing unknown risks
   - Example: Checking for earnings announcements

06:00 - Bad Risk: Misunderstood Risk
   - Understanding true risk in trade structures
   - Example: Comparing vertical spreads to naked puts

07:30 - Good Risk: Defined Risk
   - Importance of clearly defined risk
   - Analyzing risk vs. profit potential

08:30 - Good Risk: Researched Risk
   - Importance of researching potential risks
   - Example: Checking for market events and news

09:30 - Good Risk: Accepted Risk
   - Understanding and accepting risk in broader systems
   - Example: Risk in earnings plays

10:30 - Asymmetric Return Profiles
   - Creating trades with asymmetric return profiles
   - Example: VIX ratio call diagonal trade

12:00 - Best Practices for Managing Risk
   - Defining risk in every trade
   - Researching potential risks and assessing risk-reward profiles

13:00 - Conclusion
   - Summary of key points
   - Encouragement to evaluate risk and reward carefully
   - Invitation for viewer feedback and questions


▬ EVENTS  ▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬
►Weekly Monday Night YouTube Live - 5pm PT
►Weekly Outlier Pro Patreon Workshops - Discord/Zoom

▬ AFFILIATES  ▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬

text: AMD defining that risk that's a good risk to take because then we can analyze that defined risk that we're setting compared to the profit potential and see if it makes sense next is unknown risk I call this researched risk but essentially this is just where we don't have things sneaking up on us so again if I'm trading AMD I know to look when does it have earnings does it have any big news that's on the road map that's going to happen while I'm in the trade and then we have misunderstood versus accepted risk you can have for example risk in an earnings play where there's an overnight move that's really big if you accept that risk as part of a broader system and it still makes sense that's a great example of accepted risk it's something that you've analyzed even if that risk is realized in a broader system it still works out okay it still makes sense that is an example of good risk another great example of good risk is when you can create an asymmetric return profile I have a recent trade that I talked about in another video in the vix that was a vix ratio called diagonal where I was trading this to the upside when I was placing this trade it was on the 15th of September just as the market started fall well the market was very very relaxed but the vix fell below 13 so to me

text: that was a vix ratio called diagonal where I was trading this to the upside when I was placing this trade it was on the 15th of September just as the market started fall well the market was very very relaxed but the vix fell below 13 so to me that was a spot I was interested in getting long long story short I looked at the upside potential compared to what I considered to be the near-term downside potential where I was defining the risk in the trade and this was essentially the downside risk I was accepting about a dollar move in the vix to the downside compared to what I thought could be an 8 plus move to the upside that's an asymmetric return profile that was created by defining the risk that is another great example of good risk so let's talk about some best practices first probably guess this every single trade that goes on needs to have risk defined it doesn't always have to be structurally defined but you have to Define it as a Trader the second thing is we researched the potential risks to the trade so that we know about them at least and then we can assess the overall risk-reward profile of the trade to make sure it makes sense that is an idea that most Traders forgo because they will look at something like a high win rate and they're automatically on board because they just think it's a

text: at least and then we can assess the overall risk-reward profile of the trade to make sure it makes sense that is an idea that most Traders forgo because they will look at something like a high win rate and they're automatically on board because they just think it's a high win rate how could you lose you can still lose money long term that's why it is so important to look at the risk reward profile and the expected return of that strategy over the long run so that's a general rundown of good versus bad risk if there's anything I missed throw it in the comments below don't forget like subscribe be an outlier I'll see you guys later
